channel.title: tir
channel.description: "Today I Read:" a collection of the little things you read each day. Cherish them!

item.title: Observer
item.description: "The possibility of opening a terrace on life and making known all its riches, is, it seems to me, one of the many uses the cinema," and "If something doesn't work, we can still see Mr. Marcel who comes with a screwdriver to fix what didn't work... In the end, to give, to try to give a little humanity."

item.title: We Interrupt This Broadcast to Bring You an Especially Cursed House
item.description: A McMansion Hell post extreme enough to merit inclusion here.

item.title: Andrei Tarkovsky and Contemporary Art: Medium and Meditation
item.description: That paper about Tarkovsky and orthodox iconography.

item.title: Where do Eels Come From?
item.description: For a long time nobody knew from whence eels came.

item.title: Sharing and Owning Standards
item.description: Compares/contrasts standards and APIs. Dovetails neatly with my reading on RSS (a syndication standard delegates representing and ordering content).

item.title: Salt Fat Acid Defeat
item.description: Some spurious arguments about restaurant financing/the global food economy, but strong takes re. pre-Covid restaurant nostalgia.

item.title: The Drenching Richness of Andrei Tarkovsky
item.description: Decent overarching review, though it undersells "The Sacrifice." Mostly notable because it's a critic I like reviewing a director I like.

item.title: Clubhouse's Inevitability
item.description: "Democratization, aggregation, transformation;" mostly interesting inasmuch as it describes e.g. YouTube to Instagram to TikTok.

item.title: Systems design explains the world: volume 1
item.description: Stretches the definition of "systems design" a bit, but sums up the importance of valuing second- and third-order capacities on eng teams.

item.title: Modules, monoliths, and microservices
item.description: Module boundaries (codebase segments) can adhere to Conway's Law. Service boundaries (deployment) should serve ops requirements. Maybe they should even default monolithic.

item.title: Why Programmers Should(n't) Learn Theory
item.description: Ranks areas of theory from most useful (type theory) to least useful (category theory).
